author: Grimms
text: There was once upon a time an old fox with nine tails, who believed that his wife was not faithful to him, and wished to put her to the test.

author: Grimms
text: He stretched himself out under the bench, did not move a limb, and behaved as if he were stone dead.

author: Grimms
text: Mrs Fox went up to her room, shut herself in, and her maid, Miss Cat, sat by the fire, and did the cooking.

author: Grimms
text: When it became known that the old fox was dead, suitors presented themselves.

author: Grimms
text: The maid heard someone standing at the housedoor, knocking.

author: Grimms
text: She went and opened it, and it was a young fox, who said:

author: Grimms
text: "What may you be about, Miss Cat?

author: Grimms
text: Do you sleep or do you wake?"

author: Grimms
text: She answered:

author: Grimms
text: "I am not sleeping, I am waking, Would you know what I am making?

author: Grimms
text: I am boiling warm beer with butter, Will you be my guest for supper?"

author: Grimms
text: "No, thank you, miss," said the fox, "what is Mrs Fox doing?"

author: Grimms
text: The maid replied:

author: Grimms
text: "She is sitting in her room, Moaning in her gloom, Weeping her little eyes quite red, Because old Mr Fox is dead."

author: Grimms
text: "Do just tell her, miss, that a young fox is here, who would like to woo her."

author: Grimms
text: "Certainly, young sir."

author: Grimms
text: The cat goes up the stairs trip, trap, The door she knocks at tap, tap, tap, "Mistress Fox, are you inside?"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, yes, my little cat," she cried.

author: Grimms
text: "A wooer he stands at the door out there."

author: Grimms
text: "What does he look like, my dear?"

author: Grimms
text: "Has he nine as beautiful tails as the late Mr Fox?"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, no," answered the cat, "he has only one."

author: Grimms
text: "Then I will not have him."

author: Grimms
text: Miss Cat went downstairs and sent the wooer away.

author: Grimms
text: Soon afterwards there was another knock, and another fox was at the door who wished to woo Mrs Fox.

author: Grimms
text: He had two tails, but he did not fare better than the first.

author: Grimms
text: After this still more came, each with one tail more than the other, but they were all turned away, until at last one came who had nine tails, like old Mr Fox.

author: Grimms
text: When the widow heard that, she said joyfully to the cat:

author: Grimms
text: "Now open the gates and doors all wide, And carry old Mr Fox outside."

author: Grimms
text: But just as the wedding was going to be solemnized, old Mr Fox stirred under the bench, and cudgelled all the rabble, and drove them and Mrs Fox out of the house.
